nodes.bodyText:
With these changes the WebSocketClient can load and use the jetty-websocket-httpclient XML file with server class access, but we still don't have access to classes like HttpClient in the webapp. So this line will result in an exception.
And if instead of doing the line runThrowExceptionsAsRuntime(() -> finalClient.start()); and I do as intellij suggests and use runThrowExceptionsAsRuntime(finalClient::start); then I get an exception as it doesn't know LifeCycle.

I don't think you need ThrowingRunnable (can't you use Callable instead?).
Plus it's not clear what line is the problem -- there should be a comment in the code if it's non trivial due to class loading.
I'd like an explanation that there are 2 cases (webapp classes vs server classes), and what happens in each case.

Callable doesn't work because it still throws exception. I guess I could just put a nested try catch block that wraps the exception with RuntimeException. I just thought it would be cleaner with the method reference and was surprised that it didn't work.
I'd like to see also a test case for wss, as loading the SSL classes may have a similar problem to loading the http client classes.

newHttpClient() already catches all exception, so there is no need for this catch block here.
Merge the error messages and I think it should be a LOG.info(), since if we cannot load it we just fall back.
This class extends a deprecated class -- should this class be deprecated as well?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -42,10 +37,8 @@
 
 public class WebSocketExtensionFactory extends ExtensionFactory implements LifeCycle, Dumpable

nodes.bodyText: Worth clarifying the comment in: "Cannot instantiate an HttpClient here because it's a server class, and therefore must rely on jetty-websocket-httpclient.xml".

I cannot comment on the keystore file, but I don't think it's necessary.
The keystore is copied from module ssl, no? The one you added here is not used at all. If that's the case, remove it.
Worth adding a comment about what these 2 lines do -- I cannot grok it.
